Award.AwardTitle: EXP: Collaborative Research: Engaging Interdisciplinary Students in Innovation Education through Crowd-based Technology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project team is exploring how crowd-based technology can support innovation education through feedback from potential customers and users, specifically looking at how the new forms of authentic feedback can be put to good use to support learning better to design, solve problems, and innovate. Research is around issues in learning through collaborations with potential consumers mediated by technology. What are the affordances of crowd-based technology that can support learning to design, learning to innovate, learning to use feedback well, and learning to effectively iterate towards an effective and innovative result? How does use of such technology and interactions need to be scaffolded to such learning? What crowd-based activities and what types of design challenges afford such learning? Foundations are in Learning by Design (LBD), thick authenticity, and Project-Based Science (PBS).

A key to America's economic and social prosperity depends on people's ability to innovate social and technical solutions. Crowd-based technologies provide opportunities for innovators to interact with potential consumers and experts while innovating, but they have not been used in innovation education. Feedback from crowds could, however, be used to provide learners an opportunity to receive rich informative feedback on design ideas and to develop solutions that fit real-world needs. This project will contribute to our nation's ability to better prepare engineers for innovation. The technology suggested here will, if successful, make opportunities for experiencing both the difficulties of innovating and the kinds of support structures that can help and will provide an infrastructure for helping potential innovators learn to use feedback from others wisely. In addition, the results of this project will contribute towards enhancing project-based experiences throughout the curriculum. What is learned in this project about supporting learning to design, learning to innovate, learning to use feedback well, and learning to effectively iterate towards an effective result has potential to inform the effective use of project-based and design-based classes across grades and disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Technical and social innovation has been the key to the United States’ prosperity. In a climate of international competition and national economic uncertainty, there is an increasing need for strong innovators – individuals who can understand real problems, creatively generate solutions, build and test mock-ups, and pitch and carry them forward to implementation. To prepare students for careers in innovation, industry and government rely on higher education to deliver the best possible innovation education.

However, educating young people about the innovation process can be difficult, especially in classroom settings, which typically lack interaction with consumers and provide little support for actually launching solutions. To facilitate an authentic environment, many institutes have integrated interdisciplinary project-based learning approaches into their formal curricula. This project-centered approach is an improvement over traditional lecture-based and content-centered classes. While this approach effectively teaches students about teamwork and open-ended problem solving, there are limitations. Formative feedback on students’ ideas typically only comes from a handful of expert instructors or target users. The resulting student experience may bear little resemblance to the tasks and feedback associated with real-world innovation. Therefore, there exists a need for instructional methods and technologies for innovation education that further engage public opinion and realistic market forces. We look to online crowds as a potential source


In order to understand how crowds can serve the function of external feedback in project-based learning, we examined the qualities of crowd-based platforms that best support relevant and high-quality feedback at key decision making points in project-based learning in innovation. As a result of our empirical research, we understand which characteristics of crowd-based platforms support high quality feedback in project-based innovation courses and we have developed design principles and patterns for integrating crowd-based platforms into project-based learning environments. We also designed in-class activities/demonstrations, and homework for teaching how to engage the crowd at key decisions making points in project-based learning. Examples include Ideating with a Crowd, Collecting Needfinding Data through Facebook, and Consumer Analysis Through Online Reviews. We developed survey instruments capable of collecting design feedback for multiple student teams and then used the feedback to create reports for students as well as survey instruments with questions to capture demographics, prior experience with crowd-based platforms, and project-based learning experience as well as measures of computer self-efficacy, innovation self-efficacy, comprehension of crowd-based techniques, and innovation process.
